This is my 2003 Mercedes-Benz E500. I just bought it, and it set me back less than $5000... let me explain how much car that is for the money.
It's got a big v8 and it's fast. (0-60 in 5.7), handles much better than you'd expect, especially in sport mode. The steering is HEAVY and feels just so nice after driving cars with light steering for years. And as a Mercedes that originally stickered for big money, it's... luxurious. The brand new air suspension can be pretty stiff in sport mode, but while in comfort it delivers fluffy cloud ride quality. And then there's the interior. Simply draped in leather and wood with a level of fit and finish that is nothing short of remarkable. the sound system is glorious, producing bass that shakes the car and levels of volume that will easily deafen you.
to everyone about to comment "a cheap Mercedes is the most expensive car you can buy" , I'm not as dumb as you think: this car is not like most cheap Mercs.
I picked it up from a wealthy business man who had meticulously maintained it for 15 years, and had driven it just 92,000 miles after he bought it new. He also did me a huge service by replacing all four corners of the air suspension which is what always goes wrong with these cars and costs huge money.
Overall, If I tried to explain just how much I love my 500 black Benz to a non car enthusiast, he or she would think I was a ridiculous person, but I have a feeling you all will understand :)

>TL;DR can we all agree this was a solid purchase?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18647106
not all the efficiency. definitely wrong there.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18646761
>>18637955
>>18637152
Centrifugal superchargers deliver power over the whole rpm range and more power the higher the rpm is....

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18647106
So it's limited by a fixed ratio to the crankshaft. Whilst a turbocharger's boost threshold can be applied to a greater RPM range, the centrifugal blower is limited to being spun progressively as revs are increased. Great for high end power, shit for the low-mid range.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18647146
Actually, a centrifugal can get better efficiency. It's the same compressor, but you can better keep it in it's efficient RPM range.

>>18647172
>Deliver more boost the higher the RPM is
FTFY. Boost does not always equal power.

>>18647181
You could also just make a centrifugal hit peak boost at 3K RPM, and use a BOV to bleed the excess boost from 3K to redline.

Alternatively, ProCharger is currently making the I1, which puts a transmission between the pulley and the wheel, instead of the usual gearset. You can then gear it for both low and high RPM, or low and high boost levels depending on octane availability. Rotrex is working on CVT units, too. If you know how a Prius drivetrain works, kinda like that. They use a pulley and a 12V (or 48V) input to basically keep the supercharger at high RPM, no matter the engine RPM. So no, centrifugals aren't limited by a fixed ratio.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I went to COTA last weekend with a friend and watched the SCCA tour races. I have no idea what they mean by tour but it was cool.

My friend had a friend who was racing in a class with what looked like small can-am cars with Ford engines. His car looked like a POS but other cars looked perfect. There seemed to be a big difference in all the cars - some looked brand new and some were dented and generally fucked-up.

How does does this happen. Why do they let cars that have been damaged race?

Also; how much does this really cost? My friend said he bought a full race suit and helmet and took a driver school and it cost over $5000! How much does a ford race car cost?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18647918
If a car passes the technical inspection and the frame is solid it doesn't matter if the body work is damaged, it can still race.
A lot of low to mid level SCCA races are basically Advanced Amateur level. Self-funded private teams that don't always have the money to fix cosmetic body damage until next season.
And yes, racing is an expensive sport.
Even a 24 Hours of LeMons series will set you back a few grand after the car, entry fees, safety equipment, transportation costs, fuel costs, etc.
The cheapest motorsport is probably autocross, where you drive around a bunch of cones in an empty lot. At the most basic level all you need is a road-worthy car, a helmet and a $50 entrance fee.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>18646666
Use citrus flush...

Run water through everything, including open heater core. I just use a hose for the flush...don't waste your money on distilled for the flush. Be sure you open the block drain. Then run liquid shout through the system. Then flush that until clear. The run citrus flush through the system. Flush that till it's clear.

And the use distilled water and the correct coolant. Or buy pre-mixed.

Citrus flush can be found, if you look. You can buy enough to flush 1 car at any Mercedes-Benz dealership for abou 15-20 bucks.

The same reason exists everywhere else.
Without a Good Samaritan/accident protection law, a large minority of drivers will try and kill the victim
Mainly because the costs of compensation for the victim's death, the consequent jail term and becoming a social pariah is far lower than
paying for the Victim's hospital bills for life (Yes! For Life).
https://www.pri.org/stories/2011-06-03/china-economics-killing-someone

Even getting the Death penalty was considered better than ending up bankrupt and landing you and your family in debt slavery.
Most of these were village people, unlicensed drivers & drivers at the end-of-their-rope (Dipshit teens, newbies & women drivers).

The reason why most people in China did not intervene and instead just called the cops/ambulance is that if they did, the lack of a Good Samaritan law in the past meant they are at the mercy of the victim aka even if they don't get involved, they can get successfully sued and be made to pay for treatment for the accident which they didn't even cause.
http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/opinion/2011-01/05/content_11794724.htm

Of course, there are kind lads who help out if shit hit the fan but they are never the ones to get into accidents in the first place.

And of course, there are the retards who intentionally let themselves get hit by cars so they can claim compensation (From both the driver and the insurance company).
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/21/world/asia/china-traffic-scam-fraud.html

I Agree with a fuel pressure check. Spark plugs / wires are cheap and easy, and the wrong plugs/gaps can cause problems. If these are all good, consider fuel injectors, cap and rotor. Sea foam is helpful if you have dirty injectors. Also do you use cheap gas? Bad gas can be a issue.
